questions.text: RBC uses which of the following substances during fasting/starvation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucose RBCs always uses glucose whether it is fed state or fasting/starvation state because RBCs lack mitochondria. As ketone body utilization and fatty acid oxidation both take place in mitochondria so, RBCs cannot use fatty acids & ketone bodies as energy source.

Solution:

Knock down Gene knock ‘out’ → gene moved or taken 'out' Gene knock ‘in’ → gene inserted Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vit B12 Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hormone sensitive lipase Insulin is an anabolic hormone so activates anabolic enzymes and inhibits catabolic enzymes. Hormone sensitive lipase is a catabolic enzyme present in adipose tissue cells which causes release of fatty acids from stored TG during starvation. So, it is activated by catabolic enzyme Glucagon. Lipoprotein lipase on the other hand is an anabolic enzyme and release FA from TG of VLDL and chylomicrons in fed state.

questions.text: Glycosylated Hb (Hb-A1c) is best detected by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ion exchange HPLC based methods are gold standards for measurement of Hb-A1c. These methods further include ion exchange and affinity chromatography-based methods of which Ion exchange method is considered as the best and widely used method followed by affinity chromatography and enzymatic and immunological methods.

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RT-PCR RT-PCR is a method for detection of gene expression using reverse transcription of RNA to synthesize cDNA. Western Blot most commonly involve antigen-antibody interactions which is a.protein-protein interaction. Sanger’s method is a DNA sequencing technique by chain termination of DNA polymerization using DNA as template. G-banding is a chromosomal staining technique usually done for karyotyping analysis and involve only DNA.

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase is inhibited by all EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methane CN, CO and H2S are inhibitors of Cytochrome c Oxidase (Complex IV of ETC). They inhibit by non-competitive inhibition and this type of inhibition is mostly irreversible. For a complete list of ETC inhibitors refer to table 3.9.

questions.text: Binding site of miRNA on mRNA?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3’ UTR miRNA are small non coding RNA which function to control gene expression by gene knockdown at post transcriptional level by binding and degradation of specific mRNA. This process is also known as gene silencing and during this process miRNA formed by RNA polymerase II binds at 3’unstranslated region (UTR) of mRNA and mediates its action using a RISC and DICER mediated process. (See fig 14.11)

questions.text: Protein of HPV that inactivates Retinoblastoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E7 with Rb High-risk human papilloma virus (HPV) encodes two oncoproteins, E6 and E7, which are vital to viral replication and contribute to the development of cervical cancer. HPV16 E7 can target over 20 cellular proteins, but is best known for inactivating the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes/diagnostic marker is incorrectly paired?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s Defect in Beta glucocerebrosidase is associated with sphingolipid lysosomal storage disorder known as Gaucher’s disease Whereas Von Gierke’s disease is caused due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose-6-phosphatase.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Hepatolenticular degeneration also known as Wilson’s disease is due to defect in ATP7B gene causing defective biliary excretion of copper and accumulation of copper in liver. There is decrease in plasma ceruloplasmin serving as marker. Option C. In normal person, LDH-2 is more than LDH-1 in serum. BUT in myocardial infarction, LDH-1>>LDH-2. This is known as Flipped ratio of LDH in Myocardial Infarction. Option D. lipase and amylase are increased in plasma in case of Pancreatitis hence they serve as marker enzymes for pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for protein precipitation?

options.label: C
options.text: Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

questions.correct_answer: C. Change in pH other than isoelectric pH
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Change in pH other than isoelectric pH Only at Isoelectric pH, protein’s net charge is zero, known as Zwitterion. This structure is insoluble, so precipitates out. At acidic pH, protein has positive charge. At alkaline pH, protein has negative charge. The other methods of protein precipitation are: Precipitating Agent Mechanism of precipitation Heat, Strong mineral acids (H 2 SO 4 , HNO 3 , HCl) By denaturation Heavy metal salts, Alkaloidal reagents (Trichloroacetic acid, Phospho-tungstic acid, Sulfosalicylic acid) By neutralization of charges Organic solvents (ether and alcohol) and Neutral salts (e.g. Ammonium sulfate) By dehydration

questions.text: What is seen in G6PD deficiency?

options.label: D
options.text: decrease scavanging of RBC by macrophages

questions.correct_answer: B. decrease generation of reduced glutathione
questions.explanation:
Solution:

decrease generation of reduced glutathione In glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency, NADPH production is highly decreased through HMP. In the red blood cells, which lack mitochondria, HMP is the only pathway through which NADPH can be generated. In the absence of NADPH, the molecule which protects against oxidative damage (reduced glutathione) is present in oxidized form and needs to be converted back to reduced glutathione (the protective form). The enzyme that does this, glutathione reductase, requires NADPH to supply the electrons to reduce the oxidized glutathione. In the absence of NADPH, the glutathione cannot be reduced, and the protection offered by reduced glutathione is eliminated, leading to membrane damage and cell lysis.

questions.text: Positive charge in thick ascending loop of Henle is maintained by recirculation of which cation:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

K+ The thick ascending loop of Henle (TAL) is impermeable to water but there is active reabsorption of Na, Cl and K. The cotransporter in membrane of TAL is responsible for reabsorption of 1/3 of both Na and Cl in the body. On the basolateral side there is Na/K ATPase pump which throws sodium out and K in. This K + is transported back into lumen through Renal outer medullary K + channel (ROMK) channel for it to be recirculated.

questions.text: Which of the following supplement is required more for a lactating woman than the pregnant female?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vit A Table: Vitamins and mineral requirement for pregnant and lactating women Nutrient Pregnant Lactation Vitamin A (μg/d) 770 1300 Vitamin E (mg/d) 15 19 Folate (μg/d) 600 500 Thiamin (mg/d) 1.4 1.4 Vitamin B 12 (μg/d) 2.6 2.8 Vitamin C (mg/d) 85 120 Iron (mg/d) 27 9 The above table shows the Vitamins A and C are required in significantly higher quantity during the lactation while Folate and iron are required in higher quantity during pregnancy. All other minerals and vitamin (Not shown in table) have similar requirements under both conditions.

questions.text: Sideroblastic anemia can be treated by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyridoxine In sideroblastic anemia, there is impaired ability of bone marrow to produce normal RBCs resulting in production of ringed sideroblasts There is excess iron accumulation in cells leading to cellular death and ultimately resulting in sideroblastic anemia. Some of the cases of sideroblastic anemia is due to vitamin B 6 (Pyridoxine) deficiency. As pyridoxine is a coenzyme for ALA synthase its deficiency may result in reduced protoporphyrin and heme synthesis resulting in sideroblastic anemia. So, a supplementation of pyridoxine may help alleviate this condition.

questions.text: Which fusion exocytosis complex is affected in tetanus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Synaptobrevin The light chain of tetanospasmin cleave the Gln76-Phe77 bond of synaptobrevin which is an integral V-SNARE necessary for vesicle fusion to membranes in CNS and thus by cleaving this SNARE, TeNT has the effect of interfering with exocytosis of neurotransmitters such as γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons causing violent spastic paralysis.
